sub_title: Architect and City Planner | MSc Climate-Resilient Cities | Water-Sensitive Urbanism | Innovation
summary:
72% Water.

Mila Avellar Montezuma is an Architect, Urbanist and Landscaper from Federal University of Pernambuco UFPE (2019) and MSc candidate on Sustainable Urban Waters Management and Climate-Resilient Cities (UNESCO-IHE, TU-Delft, IHS-Erasmus). Her interests are related to Sustainable Urban Development, Resilient Territories to Climate Change, Integrating Structures Wildlife + Human Life, and Social Impact Entrepreneurship. She has developed activities in various fields: public, private and third sectors, integrating with various processes of transdisciplinary knowledge such as prototyping, laboratories, national and international workshops, Urban Thinkers Campos Recife (2015), III UN-Habitat in Quito-Ecuador (2016), participated in the Architectural Association - London UK developing adaptability projects in Mamori Lake – Amazon Rainforest: Floating Architecture (2017), Resilience and Adaptation (2018) and Tropical Skins (2019). She Conceived, Developed and Coordinate Strategic Projects in Architectural and Urbanistic offices (2018 – Currently). Additionally, she is the Brazilian Executive Coordinator of the International Forum – Recife Exchange Netherlands (2020-2021) project “Water as Heritage: Visions and Strategies regarding rising sea levels in Recife” and a researcher at the UFPE (2019 - Currently). Furthermore, she Published a book Chapter “Coronavirus and Brazilian cities: reflections during the Pandemic” (2020), several Articles (2020-2021) and participated of debates. Through her final thesis "o8 Amphibian Membrane | Urban strategies for the Amphibian City 16th global hotspot - Recife", Mila have been investigating the relationship of climate change in coastal cities, as well as its technological solutions: for, with and by nature.

treasury_media.title: RXN-2021-2023 | Water as Heritage: Heritage Strategies for water challenges in Recife and the Netherlands
treasury_media.description: The International Project Recife Exchange Netherlands (RXN 2021-2023) deepen the one decade of the strategic partnership between Brazil and Netherlands. Holland has a vast legacy in water-sensitive urbanism and Recife is the oldest Brazilian capital and it is also the world’s 16th most threatened city to global warming effects. RXN has the challenge to delve deeper into the shared challenge: what are the visions and the best urban strategies to Recife and the Netherlands avoid becoming submerged?

treasury_media.title: Good Practices: conceptual framework as a guideline for urban redevelopment (2019)
treasury_media.description: This article presents a good practice that resulted from the long-term cooperation and exchange between Brazil and the Netherlands in the context of the Shared Cultural Heritage programme. This project focused on heritage management and cultural landscapes, and in particular on urban planning and the redevelopment of Recife in Brazil. The city was founded in 1537 during the Portuguese colonisation of Brazil, and in the seventeenth century it became the capital Mauritsstad.

treasury_media.title: Amphibian Membrane: To prevent Recife from submerging
treasury_media.description: Cover story of issue 172.5 of AlgoMais magazine about the advance of sea level in Recife, its risk of disappearance and the initial hypothesis of a sustainable solution built in time and space: the concept of Amphibian Membrane.

treasury_media.title: RECIFE EXCHANGES | Amsterdam, Holland, Netherlands
treasury_media.description: Recife Exchanges é um dos livros que fazem parte da Coleção Recife 500 Anos desenvolvida pela Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, pela Companhia Editora de Pernambuco e pelo Observatório do Recife. Os 500 anos de fundação da capital – a mais antiga do Brasil –, estimulam reflexões sobre sua urbanização, da colonização ao Recife do futuro. O diversificado conteúdo da Coleção resulta de debates técnicos com especialistas de Pernambuco, do Brasil e do exterior da(s) cidade(s) aquacêntricas.

treasury_media.title: Vaccinated Cities: Urban and Environmental trials for a Post Pandemic Brazil
treasury_media.description:
The collection brings together 50 essays with the collaboration of 66 experts linked to urban issues, such as architects and urban planners, economists, historians, engineers, lawyers, sociologists, NGO's, parliamentarians, among others, who will discuss their propositions, questions and related ideas the end of that pandemic - or the postponement of the next one.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ehx3rVws8eI 

digital format: ISBN No. 978-65-87913-35-3
printed format: ISBN No. 78-65-87913-34-6,

treasury_media.title: (2019) Tropical Skins
treasury_media.description:
The AA Visiting School Amazon - Tropical Skins (2019) workshop explored the concept of “Tropical Skins”, which has a systemic response by adjusting the flows between inside and outside, which can be applied from these fabrics, to “second skins” (such as clothing) as well as to facades in buildings.

Through studies and analyses of local species and its systems, we prototyped structures of "skins" in different ways and scales, adapted to the climate of the Amazon Rainforest.

treasury_media.title: (2016) Brazilian Group Helds "Side Event" in the III UN - Habitat
Coronavírus and Cities in Brazil: reflections during the Pandemic (2020)
treasury_media.description: Architects and city planners, economists, historians, social scientists, engineers and philosophers involved in urban planning joined in the project for the book “Coronavirus and the cities in Brazil: reflections during the pandemic”. Analyzing causes and effects, the authors approach the main urban issues of a sick city of Covid-19 from different angles and approaches. Among authors like Raquel Rolnik and Ermínia Maricato, Mila wrote the chapter: "Epidemics and Climate Change: from ego to echo"

awards.title: (2017) Nominee of the Climate Action Challenge - Amazon Climate Change Learning Center
awards.description:
CCLC – CLIMATE CHANGE LEARNING CENTRE
A floating centre to educate Mamori Lake people and help them imagine the changes they need to make in their lives in adapting to shortages or disasters caused by climate change.

DESCRIPTION
Climate change is provoking more radical tidal variations in the Mamori Lake. Katia and Jerson lost their house in 2012 because the river water raised to record levels. Three years later, in 2015, they struggled to grow crops and to fish due to a severe drought.

The advent of electricity in 2010 brought air conditioning changing the vernacular architecture and moving away from local knowledge and technologies. New materials that are not fit for purpose, such as aluminium roofs and PVC ceilings are also being introduced, creating hotter and more uncomfortable homes.

Nadir, Jerson’s sister, and her family suffered dengue because of water polluted with organic matter. Due to the lack of a sewage system, families have been polluting the lake for decades increasing the chances to get water-borne diseases such as dengue.

The project aims to design and build a floating Climate Change Learning Centre as an example for best practice in construction to educate Mamori Lake people and serve as an scalable global case study. The project will be developed and constructed with local people, materials and technology while demonstrating a more resilient and comfortable dwelling type. Inspired by nature and using biomimicry, the building floats to adapt to tidal variations, is synergetic to resist strong storms, is based on passive cooling and closed loop nutrient systems, is affordable and easy to build. The centre will be sustained by a yearly program with visiting students and learning activities for the local schools and communities.


TEAM
Alessandra Araújo, André Almeida, Beatriz Villar, Breno Sá Leitão, Carolina Bins Ely, Gabriela Wiss, James Barcelona, Laura Cardone, Marko Brajovic, Mia T. Hjaere, Mila Montezuma, Nacho Martí, Victor Delaqua.

awards.title: Bronze Medal in the XVII Brazilian Astronomy and Astronautics Olympiad (OBAA)
awards.description: The Brazilian Astronomy and Astronautics Olympiad tests students abilities in these fields in the whole country. OBA's main goal is to encourage students to use and develop their knowledge in the study of astronomy and astronautics, identify young talents, encourages educators to improve teaching, integrate students from different schools and realities. Top medalists can go on to compete in regional and international competitions, representing Brazil.
awards.issuer: Brazilian Astronomical Society (SAB) and Brazilian Space Agency (AEB)

awards.title: Approved in all stages of the Brazilian Physics Olympiad (OBF - 2012, 2013, 2014)
Diploma of Honor to the Merit at the Brazilian Chemistry Olympiad (OBQ)
awards.description:
Brazilian Chemistry Olympiad - OBQ is an annual national chemistry competition. It aims to encourage students' interest in chemistry and discover young talents. The Brazilian Chemistry Olympiad is a competitive event, which begins annually in August, for high school and technological students. It is currently promoted by the Extension Deans of the Federal University of Ceará and by the Federal University of Piauí and has the participation of students from all units of the federation.

OBQ is also the method of selecting students who will represent Brazil at the International Chemistry Olympiad (IChO) [1] and at the Iberoamerican Chemistry Olympiad
awards.issuer: Federal University of Ceará (UFC) and Federal University of Piauí (UFPI)

awards.title: Regionaly highlighted at the Brazilian Biology Olympiad (OBB)
Highlighted in Genders Study Award Essays
awards.description:
The Naíde Teodósio Award aimed to stimulate and strengthen the critical production of knowledge about gender relations, contributing to the promotion of women's rights in their diversity. The papers addressed issues such as domestic and sexist violence, the insertion of women in spaces of power, the environment, teenage pregnancy, science, aging, among others.

The initiative was the result of a partnership with the state departments of Education, Science and Technology; the foundations of the Historical and Artistic Heritage of Pernambuco and Joaquim Nabuco; in addition to Companhia Editora de Pernambuco and the Federal Institute of Education, Science and Technology of Pernambuco.

profile_positions.title: Lecturer on Analytical Architecture and Urbanism

profile_positions.description: Executive Coordinator of the International Forum Recife Exchange Netherlands project (RXN 2020-2021) which aims to deppen the one decade of the strategic partnership between Brazil and Netherlands. On top of that, Holland has a vast legacy in terms of water-sensitive urbanism, as it is generally located a few meters under the sea level. Recife is the oldest Brazilian capital that will be 500th anniversary in 2037 and it is also the world’s 16th most threatened city to global warming effects. In this sense, RXN has the challenge to delve deeper into the shared challenge: what are the visions and the best urban strategies to Recife and its cultural Heritage avoid becoming submerged due to rising sea levels caused by Climate Change? In order to illuminate these future sustainable scenarios, this Forum RXN “Heritage and water – visions and strategies” looks forward to contributing to another scope of benefits for innovative public politics practices. The project is a partnership between UFPE and RCE promoted by the Embassy of the Netherlands and executed by INCITI/UFPE and INTG.
profile_positions.title: Executive Coordinator of the International Forum - Recife Exchange Netherlands (RXN) project

profile_positions.description:
The China-Europe Cooperation on Sponge Cities (CECoSC) is an international partnership headed by: (1) North China University of Water and Electric Power; (2) Rijkswaterstaat - Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management of the Netherlands; (3) UNESCO-IHE/Delft; (4) Technology University of Delft; (5) Deltares. This Project addresses Sponge Cities and Extreme Flood management in Urban China, which is an attempt to contribute with the national movement already stablished.  https://www.rijkswaterstaat.nl/en/water/projects/china-europe-water-platform
 
As part of the Dutch Executive Board of the project (2, 3, 4, 5), I participated on a techinical mission in Zhengzhou (Sponge City pilot) into overcoming potential challenges and setting strategic ways-forward for the Sponge Cities Program (SCP). In this sense, giving a special focus on how the SCP program actually relates (and ultimately performs) in extreme urban flood risk management.
profile_positions.title: Part of the Dutch Executive Board of China-Europe Cooperation on Sponge Cities (CECoSC)

profile_positions.description:
The Recife Exchange Holland Project (RXH 2019, Recife-Holland exchange) is an initiative for the collective and collaborative construction of a Future Vision for the Sustainable Development of the territory known as Ilha de Antônio Vaz, composed of the neighborhoods of Santo Antonio, São José, Joana Bezerra and Cabanga.

Coordinated by a group of professors from the Department of Architecture and Urbanism at the Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPE), in cooperation with partners from the RCE (Dutch Cultural Heritage Agency), the RXH 2019 aims to contribute in an innovative way to the Integrated Conservation of the cultural heritage of this territory.

The approach to the problem of the territory takes place in an integrated and interdisciplinary way. The adopted methodology mixes own procedures of approaches to Integrated Urban Conservation, Sustainable Urban Development, Social Habitat Production and Water-Sensitive Urbanism. The participation of stakeholders linked to the territory is defined as an assumption of action, making everyone co-responsible for decisions and their application.

The RXH 2019 postulates that the realization of a Future Vision for the Sustainable Development of the Island of Antônio Vaz, with the Integrated Conservation of its Cultural Heritage, must be achieved through transformations in two scales: in an endogenous level to the island, in the scale of integration of the various sectors that compose it and the dynamism and complementarity between its specific dynamics; at an exogenous level, in its physical and functional articulation with the city as a whole, in the midst of the projected macro-territorial changes and the impacts exerted by them, from outside to inside the island and vice versa.
profile_positions.title: Researcher of the Recife Exchange Holland (RXH)

profile_positions.description:
Adapt the periphery of Paris to Climate Change through: Suitable climate-resilient governance, planning and design strategies following the interaction with local decision-makers, stakeholders and communities through knowledge-sharing and co-design exercises. UDCWs typical output include detailed microclimate analyses, urban analyses linking climate-resiliency and sustainability with other local priorities expressed by stakeholders, urban projects, videos and texts. 
In order to successfully tackle the multidisciplinary dimension of the urban climate challenge emerging from these objectives, the project involves an appropriate mix of complementary experience and expertise. Though combining the following focuses:
Università degli Studi di Napoli Federico II - Italy: climate-resilient urban planning and design assessment methods and design support tools.
Université Gustave Eiffel - France: urban infrastructure vulnerability and resilience assessment methods and tools.
Sorbonne Université - France: urban ecology and biodiversity, Nature Based Solutions.
Aalborg Universitet - Denmark: urban governance and planning.
University College Dublin - Ireland: urban climate science theoretical principles, assessment methods and simulation tools.
Universitat Internacional de Catalunya - Spain: urban resilience assessment and co-design approaches.
Université de Mons - Belgium: smart city planning, Net-Zero Energy district development; resilience and risk management in the urban project.
Università di Pisa - Italy: environmental justice, policy making and legislation.
IHE Delft Institute for Water Education - Netherlands: sustainable and resilient urban water management and governance.

profile_positions.description:
The Habitat III Conference reinvigorates the global commitment to sustainable urbanization, to focus on the implementation of a “New Urban Agenda”.

Habitat III (2016) was one of the first United Nations global summits after the adoption of the Post-2015 Development Agenda. It gave the opportunity to open discussions on important urban challenges and questions, such as how to plan and manage cities, towns and villages for sustainable development. The discussion of these questions shapes the implementation of new global development and climate change goals. In particular, the conference elaborates on Goal 11 of the Sustainable Development Goals: "Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable."

Habitat III invited all Member States and relevant stakeholders, including parliamentarians, civil society organizations, regional and local government and municipality representatives, professionals and researchers, academia, foundations, women and youth groups, trade unions, and the private sector, as well as organizations of the United Nations system and intergovernmental organizations.

About 30,000 people in total attended the conference, which was based at the Casa de la Cultura Ecuatoriana in Quito 2016.
profile_positions.title: Participant of the UN - Habitat III
